metadata.titleEn: AVHRR_Path Finder vegetation index dataset of long time series in China (1981-2001)
metadata.description:
The data used in this research was provided by the Pathfinder database of the EROS (Earth Resource Observation System) data center. The vegetation index NDVI was prepared by using the NOAA-AVHRR data source after radiation correction and geometric rough correction. Every day, each track image is processed with geometric fine correction, removal of bad lines, and removal of clouds, etc., and then NDVI calculation and synthesis. The daily NDVI calculation formula is: 1000 × (b2-b1) / (b2 + b1), where b1 and b2 are the first and second channels of AVHRR.

background: Earth observation-based long-term global vegetation index products are used by scientists from a wide range of disciplines concerned with global change. The normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) is defined as (ρNIR −ρRED)/(ρNIR +ρRED), where ρNIR and ρRED are surface reflectance in the near infrared (NIR; 0.725–1.10 µm) and visible red (0.58–0.68 µm), respectively. As plants become more photoactive, they absorb more visible red light due to the chlorophyll content of leaves and stems, and scatter more in the near infrared due to the alignment of cell walls. This relationship, detected by remote sensing instruments at the canopy scale, has the effect of making the index increase (decrease) as the density of the canopy increases (decreases). As such, NDVI has been used widely in global change research with Earth observation remote sensing for three general purposes: (1) the estimation of canopy properties related to light-use efficiency, such as the leaf area index (LAI) and fraction of photosynthetically active radiation intercepted by the canopy (FPAR), (2) representation of vegetation climatology in soil–vegetation–atmosphere transfer models, and (3) detection of trends in vegetation and phenology. Although NDVI is widely used, it is sensitive to atmospheric effects, soil background, and saturates at high LAI. The enhanced vegetation index (EVI) was introduced to overcome these limitations, as it includes a visible blue band to reduce atmospheric effects, calibration terms to reduce the effects of soil background, and does not saturate as severely as NDVI at high LAI. The Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) is the most commonly used sensor for long-term (i.e. pre-MODIS) global change studies, because it began retrieving visible red and NIR reflectance needed to estimate NDVI from 1981. Reflectance data collected from the earlier AVHRR sensors were difficult to process and synthesize, because they lacked onboard calibration; the NIR channel was sensitive to water, sun glint, glaciers at high latitudes, and clouds; and of orbital drift. These issues were rectified with the launch of the AVHRR sensors onboard NOAA 16, 17, 18, and 19, but have resulted in radiometric and spectral inconsistencies across sensors that can significantly bias global change analyses. Various methods have been developed to make these data continuous and consistent through time, but take different approaches and are frequently updated, necessitating new accuracy assessments to inform the user community as they evolve. The Global Inventory Modeling and Mapping Studies (GIMMS) and Vegetation Index and Phenology Lab (VIP) AVHRR products are actively used and frequently updated, but represent fundamentally different approaches to synthesis. Both GIMMS and VIP are aggregated to a 15-day time step from daily data and are calibrated with higher spatial resolution sensors in the period that overlaps NOAA 7, 9, 11, and 14 and NOAA 16, 17, 18, and 19.
research objective: The aim of this study was to perform a global assessment of the latest version of GIMMS and VIP over a 30-year period (January 1982 to December 2011) in order to aid the user (global change) community in interpreting results that involve these data. In doing so, we helped resolve the superiority of one product over another. The assessment was performed with three experiments that address the three major themes of global change research that involve Earth observation remote sensing.
challenges: Reflectance data collected from the earlier AVHRR sensors were difficult to process and synthesize, because they lacked onboard calibration; the NIR channel was sensitive to water, sun glint, glaciers at high latitudes, and clouds; and of orbital drift. These issues were rectified with the launch of the AVHRR sensors onboard NOAA 16, 17, 18, and 19, but have resulted in radiometric and spectral inconsistencies across sensors that can significantly bias global change analyses. Bias in inter-calibration of the VIP record at northernmost latitudes was suspected to contribute most to these discrepancies.
methods: After the filter was applied, NDVI3g was resampled to NDVI3v/EVI3v resolution using the gdalwarp utility (http://www.gdal.org/gdalwarp.html) with default parameters. The data sets were then resampled back to the native NDVI3g spatial resolution for evaluation. FPAR derived from Landsat Thematic Mapper/The Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (TM/ETM +) 30 m resolution surface reflectance data was used intermediately to downscale NDVI3g, NDVI3v, and EVI3v to 30 m resolution to facilitate the comparison. The Landsat TM/ETM+surface reflectance and in situ LAI data were extracted from a database that was developed to determine the ability of Landsat-based NDVI, EVI2, and other vegetation indices to predict LAI for field crops around the world. NDVI and EVI2 were computed using the equations above. Downscaling was performed by converting AVHRR and Landsat vegetation indices to FPAR. In this study, on a per pixel basis, most of the in situ LAI was retrieved only once, so using a ratio-based approach was not feasible. Therefore, the AVHRR vegetation indices were downscaled to 30 m spatial resolution by regressing (linearly) Landsat FPAR and NDVI3g, NDIV3v, and EVI3v FPAR. Once NDVI3g, NDVI3v, and EVI3v FPAR were downscaled to corresponding Landsat data, their performance was evaluated by regressing them (linearly) with the in situ LAI data. The performance of the final model selected in each case was characterized by the coefficient of determination (R2), significance tests, and root mean square error (RMSE).
dataset: Unlike previous global studies, a unique Landsat 30 m spatial resolution and in situ LAI database for major crop types on five continents was used to evaluate the performance of not only NDVI3g and NDVI3v but also EVI3v.
findings: The performance of NDVI3v and EVI3v was worse than NDVI3g using the in situ data, which was attributed to the fusion of GIMMS and MODIS data in the VIP record. EVI3v has the potential to contribute biophysical information beyond NDVI3g and NDVI3v to global change studies, but we caution its use due to the poor performance of EVI3v in this study. Overall, the records were most consistent at northern latitudes during the primary growing season and southern latitudes and the tropics throughout much of the year, while the records were less consistent at northern latitudes during green-up and senescence, and in the great deserts of the world throughout much of the year. These patterns led to general agreement (disagreement) between trends in the magnitude (timing) of NDVI over the study period.

background: Numerous studies have noted an incremental change in vegetation cover in different ecosystems of China and of the Northern Hemisphere between 1982 and 1999. The extent of vegetation cover is increasing significantly in West China. In the source regions of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, Wang et al. (2004) studied recent variations in several typical alpine grassland ecosystems using 1986 and 2000 Landsat TM data. High-cold grassland and alpine meadow are two primary categories of alpine vegetation in the study regions. The NDVI is a ratio involving the amounts of reflectance in the near infrared (NIR) and red (RED) portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.
research objective: Herein, the relation between the degradation of grassland ecosystems and changes in alpine vegetation in this area were studied. Calibrated-NDVI multi-temporal series data from NOAA-AVHRR images were used to analyze the temporal and spatial variation in vegetation cover and its relation to meteorological factors.
challenges: At present the authors have ground temperature data only between 0 and 40 cm depth, so this effect cannot be explored further.
methods: Areas of 3 × 3 pixels centered on Wudaoliang, TuoTuohe, QuMalai, MaDuo, and DaRi meteorological stations were selected for statistical analysis. The authors obtained simple correlations between air temperature, precipitation, ground temperature and NDVI in these areas and constructed multivariate statistical models, including and excluding the effect of ground temperature. The NDVI time series were derived from the AVHRR 10-day composite images. Maximum NDVI value was extracted in each month from per pixel in per image. The mean NDVI value is used to represent vegetation cover during the growing season of a year. A linear correlation with time was used to examine the change in NDVI in each pixel over the 20 years period. The F test was used to examine the significance of these trends.
dataset: The NDVI time series were derived from the AVHRR 10-day composite images. The time series spans 20 years, from 1982 to 2001. Meteorological data used in this work include monthly mean air temperature and monthly precipitation between 1981 and 2000, and monthly ground temperatures at 0, 10, 20, and 40 cm depth between 1981 and 1998 at these stations.
findings: The above analyses indicate that the most important factor affecting NDVI in the source regions of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers is ground temperature in deeper layers.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'FPAR' in relation to canopy property estimation from Earth observation data?
Definition.Answer: FPAR, or the fraction of photosynthetically active radiation intercepted by the canopy, is a critical variable used to estimate canopy properties related to light-use efficiency. It represents the portion of available sunlight that is absorbed by the vegetation for photosynthesis and is frequently estimated using indices like NDVI in Earth observation remote sensing for global change research.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced by earlier AVHRR sensors in global assessments compared to those encountered when analyzing the spatial and temporal variation in vegetation cover in China's alpine regions using calibrated-NDVI data?
Comparison.Answer: Earlier AVHRR sensors faced challenges such as lack of onboard calibration, sensitivity to water and sun glint, and orbital drift, impacting global assessments. In contrast, the challenges in analyzing alpine regions using calibrated-NDVI data include limited ground temperature data and the need for multivariate statistical models to correlate NDVI with meteorological factors. These challenges highlight the differences in sensor limitations versus environmental and data integration complexities.

Interpretation.Question: What can the variations in NDVI data over the 20-year period suggest about the changes in vegetation dynamics and their potential drivers in China?
Interpretation.Answer: The variations in NDVI data over the 20-year period can suggest changes in vegetation dynamics influenced by factors such as meteorological conditions, including air temperature, precipitation, and ground temperature. These factors are critical in understanding the temporal and spatial variation in vegetation cover and its relationship to environmental changes.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges of atmospheric effects and soil background interference in NDVI data be addressed to improve data accuracy and interpretation?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges such as atmospheric effects and soil background interference in NDVI data can be addressed by employing calibration terms and additional spectral bands, such as those used in the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI), which includes a visible blue band to reduce atmospheric effects and calibration terms to address soil background issues. This helps in improving the accuracy of data and its interpretation in vegetation studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulties in processing and synthesizing reflectance data from earlier AVHRR sensors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Reflectance data collected from the earlier AVHRR sensors were difficult to process and synthesize due to the lack of onboard calibration, sensitivity to water, sun glint, glaciers at high latitudes, clouds, and issues related to orbital drift.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need to develop methods for making AVHRR data continuous and consistent over time?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a need to develop methods for making AVHRR data continuous and consistent over time due to radiometric and spectral inconsistencies across sensors, which can significantly bias global change analyses.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the discrepancies in the inter-calibration of the VIP record at northernmost latitudes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Bias in inter-calibration of the VIP record at northernmost latitudes is suspected to contribute most to discrepancies due to the fusion of GIMMS and MODIS data in the VIP record.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on data consistency if different calibration methods are applied to datasets collected from AVHRR sensors over time?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying different calibration methods to datasets collected from AVHRR sensors can result in radiometric and spectral inconsistencies across sensors, which can significantly bias global change analyses. This is due to the lack of onboard calibration in earlier sensors and the sensitivity of the NIR channel to various factors such as water and clouds.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise in vegetation trend detection from using NDVI data that is sensitive to atmospheric effects and soil background?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using NDVI data that is sensitive to atmospheric effects and soil background may lead to inaccuracies in detecting trends in vegetation and phenology. NDVI can saturate at high leaf area index (LAI), potentially obscuring true vegetation trends and affecting the reliability of related global change research.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of high-resolution datasets like Landsat 30 m resolution data impact the evaluation of NDVI and EVI indices in global change studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of high-resolution datasets such as Landsat 30 m resolution data allows for a more refined evaluation of NDVI and EVI indices, facilitating the downscaling of these indices and enabling a comparison with in situ LAI data. This process helps to assess the performance and reliability of NDVI and EVI indices in capturing biophysical information for global change studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the challenges in processing reflectance data from earlier AVHRR sensors for vegetation index studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing challenges in processing reflectance data from earlier AVHRR sensors is crucial because these sensors lacked onboard calibration and were sensitive to factors like water, sun glint, and clouds. Such issues resulted in radiometric and spectral inconsistencies, which can bias global change analyses. Solving these problems ensures continuity and consistency of the data, enabling more accurate and reliable studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of using calibrated NDVI multi-temporal series data in analyzing vegetation cover changes in alpine grassland ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using calibrated NDVI multi-temporal series data in analyzing vegetation cover changes in alpine grassland ecosystems is to understand the temporal and spatial variation in vegetation cover and its relation to meteorological factors. This approach helps in studying the degradation of grassland ecosystems and assessing the impact of climatic changes on alpine vegetation, particularly in regions like the source areas of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the necessary steps to geometrically correct and preprocess AVHRR data to calculate NDVI for long-term vegetation studies in China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing of AVHRR data involves radiometric calibration and coarse geometric correction, followed by precise geometric correction, removal of bad lines, and cloud removal. This prepares the data for NDVI calculation using the formula 1000×(b2-b1)/(b2+b1), where b1 and b2 are AVHRR channel 1 and 2, respectively.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can inconsistencies in reflectance data from AVHRR sensors over time be mitigated to ensure reliable NDVI calculations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Inconsistencies due to factors like lack of onboard calibration and sensitivity to water and clouds can be addressed by applying continuous and consistent data processing methods. This includes calibrating data with higher spatial resolution sensors and resampling to facilitate accuracy assessments and reduce biases in global change analyses.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the evaluation of NDVI data accuracy using high-resolution datasets like Landsat?
Enablement.Answer: Evaluating NDVI data accuracy is enabled by methodologies that involve downscaling NDVI data using higher resolution datasets like Landsat. This involves regression analysis and the conversion of AVHRR and Landsat vegetation indices to FPAR (Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation), which is then correlated with in situ LAI (Leaf Area Index) data to assess performance and accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset collected using AVHRR sensors face challenges in achieving consistency over time?
Expectation.Answer: Reflectance data from earlier AVHRR sensors lacked onboard calibration, and the NIR channel was sensitive to water, sun glint, glaciers, and clouds, leading to radiometric and spectral inconsistencies across sensors, which can significantly bias analyses.

Expectation.Question: Why might NDVI datasets require careful methodological approaches for accurate temporal and spatial trend analyses?
Expectation.Answer: NDVI datasets can be influenced by atmospheric effects, soil background, and saturation at high leaf area index, necessitating approaches like enhanced vegetation indices and multivariate statistical models to mitigate these challenges and accurately assess trends.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using NDVI derived from AVHRR data for long-term monitoring of vegetation changes in China?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using NDVI derived from AVHRR data for long-term monitoring of vegetation changes in China can be considered significant due to its historical data availability and ability to track vegetation trends over time. However, its sensitivity to atmospheric conditions and soil background, as well as saturation at high Leaf Area Index (LAI), can affect reliability. Despite these limitations, it remains widely used for estimating canopy properties and determining trends in vegetation and phenology.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might the integration of meteorological data enhance the understanding of vegetation changes captured by NDVI in alpine grassland ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating meteorological data, such as air temperature, precipitation, and ground temperature, enhances understanding of vegetation changes by providing insight into the environmental factors influencing NDVI variations. For example, in alpine grassland ecosystems, ground temperature in deeper layers has been identified as a major factor affecting NDVI. This integration allows for the construction of multivariate statistical models to better analyze temporal and spatial variations in vegetation cover.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the calibration of NDVI data accounts for atmospheric effects and soil background.
Assertion.Answer: NDVI is sensitive to atmospheric effects and soil background, which can affect its accuracy. The Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) was introduced to overcome these limitations by including a visible blue band and calibration terms to reduce these effects, thus providing a more reliable measure in some conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection techniques used for generating long-term vegetation indices from Earth observation remote sensing and discuss the potential challenges encountered in ensuring data continuity and consistency.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection techniques for long-term vegetation indices often involve the use of sensors like NOAA's AVHRR, which capture visible red and NIR reflectance to estimate NDVI. Challenges include processing and synthesizing reflectance data due to lack of onboard calibration, sensitivity to water, sun glint, glaciers, and clouds, as well as orbital drift. These issues can lead to radiometric and spectral inconsistencies across sensors, affecting the continuity and consistency of the data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the types of datasets or data sources that can be utilized to enhance the accuracy and reliability of vegetation index studies, particularly in the context of long-term environmental monitoring.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets that can enhance vegetation index studies include high-resolution Landsat TM/ETM+ surface reflectance data and in situ LAI databases. These can be used to downscale and validate AVHRR-derived indices, improving accuracy and reliability. Additionally, meteorological data such as air temperature, precipitation, and ground temperature can provide context for analyzing temporal and spatial variations in vegetation indices.
